title: plus tipster shares advice on who to back at Doncaster
text:

With the rain that has fallen already so far in October and the forecast for more ahead of the weekend racing, the going at Doncaster for their final Flat meeting of the season is expected to be heavy.

This time of the season is tricky at the best of times with the Flat season coming to an end and the NH season starting to hit its stride, but the prospect of really heavy ground could see a few shock results on Saturday.

I want to take on the short-priced favourite in the feature race of the day at Doncaster, the Group 1 Vertem Futurity Stakes at 15:25.

Aidan O’Brien’s colt Mogul has won his last two races in good style and should go on the ground but at very short odds I’m happy to side against him with one of his four stablemates at the prices.

One thing in this ground over this trip for two-year-olds is that they’ll find it hard to make up ground in the closing stages, so I want to be with the horse most likely to be leading them into the final few furlongs, and that is Louisiana.

He won well last time albeit in a nursery handicap, but he definitely goes on the ground and stays this 1m trip really well. I can see the rest of the field leaving it to him to get on with things and if that’s the case then it should mean he’s even harder to pass. It’s a shame only six go to post in this but at 16/1 I think he rates a good bet.

And don't forget, Betfair Sportsbook are offering a free bet of up to £25 for every winner at 3/1 or over during ITV racing on Saturday (free bet matching original stake, max £25).

The ability to handle the ground, a good record of winning at this time of year, and no questions about staying the trip are all reasons why Ian Williams’ five-year-old Time To Study in the 14:55 at Doncaster rates a solid each-way bet at 12/1.

He has one win on very soft ground in France, two wins on soft and he’s been placed twice on heavy ground, so today’s ground should hold no fears. His record shows he’s won in late October in 2017 and mid-November in 2016 so we know he’s been near his best historically at this time of year. He’s also won over 1m6.5f, so this heavy ground 1m4f contest should see him staying on at the finish when plenty others may be struggling.

Throw in that he has a good 5lb claimer taking weight off his back, the superbly named Thore Hammer Hansen, and the fact that the Williams stable have had a winner this week then we have a strong case for another good each-way bet.
description: While the Nation Hunt season hits top gear there’s still an excellent card on Doncaster’s final Flat meeting of the year, and Alan Thompson has two each-way bets to consider…
